articles.headline: Powell Suggests Interest Rates Could Stay High for a Longer Period
articles.snippet: The Fed chair, along with the central bank’s No. 2 policymaker, stressed uncertainties over job growth and the persistence of elevated inflation.
articles.abstract: The Fed chair, along with the central bank’s No. 2 policymaker, stressed uncertainties over job growth and the persistence of elevated inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is likely to wait longer than initially expected to cut interest rates, given stubborn inflation readings in recent months, the central bank’s top two officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Israel Weighs Response to Iran Attack, With Each Choice a Risk
articles.snippet: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities, but all carry drawbacks.
articles.abstract: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities, but all carry drawbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli leaders on Tuesday were debating how best to respond to Iran’s unprecedented weekend airstrike, officials said, weighing a set of options calibrated to achieve different strategic outcomes: deterring a similar attack in the future, placating their American allies and avoiding all-out war.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Isabel Kershner, Julian E. Barnes and Russell Goldman

articles.headline: What Can ‘Green Islam’ Achieve in the World’s Largest Muslim Country?
articles.snippet: Clerics in Indonesia are issuing fatwas, retrofitting mosques and imploring congregants to help turn the tide against climate change.
articles.abstract: Clerics in Indonesia are issuing fatwas, retrofitting mosques and imploring congregants to help turn the tide against climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: The faithful gathered in an imposing modernist building, thousands of men in skullcaps and women in veils sitting shoulder to shoulder. Their leader took to his perch and delivered a stark warning.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ulet Ifansasti

articles.headline: Inside the Late-Night Parties Where Hawaii Politicians Raked In Money
articles.snippet: After the state passed a law barring government contractors from donating to politicians, fund-raising parties showed just how completely the reform effort failed.
articles.abstract: After the state passed a law barring government contractors from donating to politicians, fund-raising parties showed just how completely the reform effort failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the better part of a decade, some of Hawaii’s most powerful people huddled together at late-night parties in a cramped second-floor office where lobbyists and executives seeking government contracts lined up to drop cash and checks into a metal lockbox.
articles.byline: By Blaze Lovell, Eric Sagara and Irene Casado Sanchez

articles.headline: VW Workers in Tennessee Start Vote on U.A.W., Testing Union Ambitions
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers hopes contract gains at the Big Three carmakers will provide momentum in a broad effort to organize nonunion plants.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers hopes contract gains at the Big Three carmakers will provide momentum in a broad effort to organize nonunion plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall the United Automobile Workers union won big pay increases from the Detroit automakers, and the impact rippled quickly through the nonunion auto plants scattered across the South.

articles.headline: Women Talk Through Their Abortions on TikTok
articles.snippet: At a time of heightened confusion and legal battles over access to abortion, women are looking to social media for answers.
articles.abstract: At a time of heightened confusion and legal battles over access to abortion, women are looking to social media for answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Have an abortion with me,” a single mother from Brooklyn named Sunni says as she twirls around her kitchen to light jazzy piano, before walking TikTok viewers through the steps she took to end her pregnancy at home.

articles.headline: Trains, Trucks and Tractors: The Race to Reroute Goods From Baltimore
articles.snippet: Since the collapse of the Key Bridge, other East Coast ports have absorbed the cargo previously handled in Baltimore, but some parts of the supply chain like trucking are struggling.
articles.abstract: Since the collapse of the Key Bridge, other East Coast ports have absorbed the cargo previously handled in Baltimore, but some parts of the supply chain like trucking are struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: New John Deere tractors made their way last week through the sprawling port of Brunswick, Ga., their distinctive green paint glinting in the sunshine. Dock workers drove the tractors up a ramp into the belly of the Leo Spirit, a ship that would take them to Asia.
